moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3
comment: An improvement over the classical line 8.Bd3 Nxc3 9.Bd2 (or 9.a3 Na2+ 10.Bd2 Bxd2+ 11.Kxd2 c5 12.Rxa2 Nc6 with advantage to Black) 9...Nxa2 10.c3 Nxc3 11.bxc3 Be7 and Black was better in Yanovsky-Marshall, Ostende 1907.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5
comment: Accepting the gambit with 9...Nxc3 10.Bd3 Nc6 can be dangerous after 11.h4 Ne7 (11...Qe7 12.h5 g5 13.f4! was good for White in Klovan-Makarichev, USSR 1978.) 12.f3! with advantage Kurajica-Dvorecki, Wijk aan Zee I 1976.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4
comment: White's pieces are well developed and ready to attack the weakened Black kingside.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5
comment: Provoking the following piece sacrifice. More reliable was 12...Bd7 or 12...Nc6.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8
comment: Of course, Black cannot take the bishop immediately - 14...fxg6? 15.Qxg6+ Kf8 when either 16.Be3 or 16.f4 gives White a strong attack.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6
comment: White has already three pawns for the piece with a raging attack, but the success of White's intuitive sacrifice depends on whether Black has chances to evacuate his King to the Queenside and consolidate his forces. My opponent almost succeeded.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7
comment: Intending to protect the kingside. 18...Re8 looks more sensible, but it fails to 19.Qf6+ Kc7 (if 19...Re7 20.Ng6 wins) 20.Nxd5+!

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1
comment: Threatening to attack the d5-pawn with 20.c4. Such forcing threats are the best tactical resource in positions where the opponent has not finished his development. 19.Bxc5 Qxc5 20.Nxe6+ Bxe6 21.Qxe6 is weaker.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4
comment: Consistent. 20.Bxc5 Qxc5 21.Qxe6 Rf8 22.Qh6 Kc7 looks attractive but is unclear.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8
comment: Not 20...dxc4? 21.Bxc5 Qxc5 22.Nxe6+ and White wins.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4
comment: A serious error. Correct was 21.cxd5 exd5 (or 21...Nxd5 22.Nxd5 exd5 23.Qf6+ Kc7 24.Qd6+ Kd8 25.e6 winning) 22.c4! with a decisive attack.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5
comment: I overlooked this nice resource. The threat of 22...Nf3+ gives Black a chance to organize a counterattack.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1
comment: Not 23.Nxe6+ Bxe6 24.dxe6 Nf3+ 25.Kh1 Nxh4 26.Bb6+ Ke8 27.Bxa5 Rxg2 and Black wins.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7
comment: Intending to safeguard the King, and at the same time, to connect the rooks. Other tries are likely to favor White, e.g., 24...exd5 25.Nxd5 Nxd4 (if 25...Rxc2 26.e6! or 25...Rc4 26.Nf6) 26.Rxd4 Qc5 27.Rad1 with the initiative.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1
comment: Black has consolidated his forces and is now on top. He has the option of pursuing a number of promising continuations, e.g., 27...exd5 28.Nxd5 Nxd4 29.Rxd4 Ne6; 27...Nxd4; 27...Ba4 28.Rd2 Bb3; 27...Qa4 with sufficient counterplay in all lines.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3
comment: My opponent - a glorious chess veteran who always sought active play - had planned to transfer his queen to the kingside for a counterattack, but he underestimated the threats on the other side of the board. This was a super-bold idea although 27...Nxd4 28.Rxd4 Qxa3 seems a better way of capturing the a-pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3 28. Bb2
comment: Avoiding the trap 28.Ra1? Nxd4! 29.Rxa3 Nxe2 and Black wins.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3 28. Bb2 Qe7 29. Ra1 Qh7 30. h3 Qh4
comment: Attacking the White knight, a key element in White's king fortress. However, Black could play more interestingly - utilizing the long-ranging queen at h7, e.g., 30...Ne4!? (Idea 31...Neg3+) 31.Ra3 Rg3! but 32.Re1! still wins for White, or 30...exd5 31.cxd5 Rc2!? 32.Qxc2! Ng3+ 33.fxg3 Qxc2 34.Bd4 a6 35.e6! and White is still on top. As we shall see, Black's counterattack is by no means naive in concept.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3 28. Bb2 Qe7 29. Ra1 Qh7 30. h3 Qh4 31. Bc1 Rcf8 32. c5
comment: With the horrible threat of 33.c6. If now 32...exd5 33.e6! My opponent now tried a desperate counterattack.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3 28. Bb2 Qe7 29. Ra1 Qh7 30. h3 Qh4 31. Bc1 Rcf8 32. c5 Nxh3 33. Nxh3 exd5 34. e6 Bc6 35. Bf4+
comment: A horrible blunder would be 35.Qe5+ Kc8 36.Rxa7? because of 36...Qxh3+!! 37.gxh3 d4+ 38.Kh2 Rg2+ and Black wins.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3 28. Bb2 Qe7 29. Ra1 Qh7 30. h3 Qh4 31. Bc1 Rcf8 32. c5 Nxh3 33. Nxh3 exd5 34. e6 Bc6 35. Bf4+ Kc8 36. Rxa7 Kd8
comment: Now 36...Qxh3+ doesn't work because of 37.gxh3 d4+ 38.f3 Ng3+ 39.Kh2 Nxe2 40.Ra8 mate.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Bb4 5. e5 h6 6. Be3 Ne4 7. Qg4 g6 8. a3 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 c5 10. Bd3 Qa5 11. Ne2 cxd4 12. Bxd4 Nc5 13. O-O Nc6 14. Bxg6 Rg8 15. Bxf7+ Kxf7 16. Qh5+ Ke7 17. Qxh6 Kd8 18. Nf4 Ne7 19. Rfd1 Bd7 20. c4 Rc8 21. Qh4 Ne4 22. cxd5 Ng5 23. Kh1 Nf5 24. Qh5 Kc7 25. Qe2 Kb8 26. c4 Qa6 27. Rac1 Qxa3 28. Bb2 Qe7 29. Ra1 Qh7 30. h3 Qh4 31. Bc1 Rcf8 32. c5 Nxh3 33. Nxh3 exd5 34. e6 Bc6 35. Bf4+ Kc8 36. Rxa7 Kd8 37. Bd6
comment: Black resigned as mate can only be avoided by great material loss.
